messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Kevin Klinemeier <zipwow@y...> wrote:
> --- Dave Astels <dave@s...> wrote:
> > So then, where does that format come from in the problem in hand?

> What I'm saying is that your tests (like your end users) don't care
> what the format is, they only care that storage and retrieval works.
> If you're working with serialization, you're not really 'defining
> the format' so much as using an existing framework.

Ah.. ok... it wasn't explicit that it was "Java Serialization" that
was being referred to. I was approaching it from a more general
perspective. I wasn't even assuming Java.

> Hmm, in this I guess I'm assuming that this thing's state is easy to
> examine after deserializing.

I would think that an assertEquals test should be adequate. Maybe
even an assertSame test if there is caching involved.

> If that's not the case for some reason, then I think you'd also want
> to think about why that's the case before just going with examining
> serialization files.

Agreed.

> > Yes. Agreed. But try to avoid using a file to do it.
>
> Definitely. Another poster (was it you, Dave?)

I believe so.

> suggested that String streams are the way to go, and I agree with
> that. If you need to share these things between tests, make them
> fixtures and share them that way.

Yes. But all you can share is the initial state... there should be no
effects from one test on another.

Dave
